1934
1933 in comics
1935 in comics

Notable events of 1934 in comics. See also List of years in comics.

Events and publications[edit]

This literature-related list is incomplete; you can help by expanding it.

January[edit]

  • January 7: Alex Raymond's Flash Gordon and Jungle Jim makes their debut.[1]
  • January 22: Dashiel Hammett and Alex Raymond's Secret Agent X-9 makes its debut and will run until 1996.

February[edit]

  • February - August: Hergé's Popol Out West is serialized in Le Petit Vingtième. [2]

March[edit]

  • March 4: The final episode of Bucky Bug as part of the Silly Symphonies feature is published. [3]
  • March 5: Frank Victor Martinek's Don Winslow of the Navy makes its debut. It will run until 30 July 1955.
  • March 19: Will Gould's Red Barry makes its debut.[4]

April[edit]

  • April: David Low's Colonel Blimp makes his debut. [5]

June[edit]

  • June 11: Lee Falk and Fred Fredericks's Mandrake the Magician makes its debut.

July[edit]

  • Famous Funnies #1 (Eastern Color Printing) - The first full-color comic book sold to the public. It set the standard of 68 pages, including covers, and sold for 10 cents. Early issues of this series, starting with #1, advertised the contents as "100 Comics and Games - Puzzles - Magic."

August[edit]

  • August 13: Al Capp's Li'l Abner makes its debut. [6]

September[edit]

  • September 16: Ted Osborne and Al Taliaferro's Silly Symphonies comic strip adapts the cartoon The Wise Little Hen, which marks the official debut of Donald Duck (who debuted in that animated short) as a comics character. [7]
  • September: Rube Goldberg's Boob McNutt comes to a close.
  • Famous Funnies #2 (Eastern Color Printing) - With this issue, Famous Funnies would become the first monthly newsstand comic publication.

October[edit]

  • October 1: Fred Neher's Life's Like That makes its debut.
  • October 7: Fred Harman's Bronc Peeler makes its debut. [8]
  • October 14: The first issue of the Italian comics magazine L'Avventuroso is published. It will run until 16 May 1943.
  • October 21: First publication of the French Disney comics magazine Le Journal de Mickey. [9] A test issue was already published on June 1, 1934.[10]
  • October 22: Milton Caniff's Terry and the Pirates makes its debut. [11]
  • Famous Funnies #3 (Eastern Color Printing)

November[edit]

  • Famous Funnies #4 (Eastern Color Printing)

December[edit]

  • December 13: E.O. Plauen's Vater und Sohn (Father and Son) makes its debut. [12]
  • Famous Funnies #5 (Eastern Color Printing)

Deaths[edit]

February[edit]

  • February 15: Louis Forton, French comics writer and artist (Les Pieds Nickelés, Bibi Fricotin, Ploum), dies at age 54. [13]
  • February 27: John Terry, American comics artist and animator (Scorchy Smith, continued Have You Seen Alonzo?), dies at age 53 or 54. [14]

July[edit]

  • July 26: Winsor McCay, American comics artist and animator (Little Nemo in Slumberland, Dream of the Rarebit Fiend, Little Sammy Sneeze, Gertie the Dinosaur) dies at age 64 from a cerebral embolism. [15]

November[edit]

  • November 23: Albert Funke Küpper, Dutch comics artist (Krelissie en Direkkie, continued Snuffelgraag en Knagelijntje), dies at age 40 in a car accident. [16]

Specific date unknown[edit]

  • August Roeseler, German cartoonist, caricaturist, illustrator and comics artist (worked for Fliegende Blätter and Simplicissimus), dies at age 77 or 78. [17]
